message: The company I work for went through a hiring process for Django devs... Apparently many part time freelance and contract, is this the usual? Also many seem to be on £350+/day :)
I feel like there's a good mix (from the people I know in the area). It's all about what you want to do, and there's plenty of people looking for Python/Django help :)

@zeeg my theory is that the Django community is very entrepreneurial, so there is a bigger proportion of good developers starting their own startups/companies. Therefore I guess demand for good devs is higher compares to other skillsets? Would that make sense? :)

@jamespaxi I wouldn't necessarily say it's higher, but there's definitely a large amount of newer Django users. Not just new to Django, but new to Python, and even some new to development. That kind of messes w/ the scales a little bit
@zeeg seems pretty easy to hire java, c# and php developers compared to python/Django devs
The age of the stack matters.. There are lots of Java or C# guys with over a decade of experience.. Becomes a bit of a numbers game.
My company is making a wholesale change from PHP to Django.  We've hired a few guys with Django experience but a lot of devs are converting.
Part time freelancing currently. Looking for something more permanent, though.

Our experience with hiring is that the average django application (looking for a fulltime position) is generally a stronger dev but looking for considerably more money than an equivalently skilled PHP dev.
I think may places make the mistake of requiring x years of experience in Django. If someone is a good developer, then can move over to Python/Django easily.
@BenBelchak depends what kind of contribution we are talking about, because even the experts in PYthon/Django world ask others for advice :)

@emperorcezar Agreed. I am employee #1 at a small startup and that is what we are finding. We would rather hire people we like and would enjoy working with than hire a kickass django developer. If you are a good developer, you can definitely pick Python/Django up very quickly.
@BenBelchak I guess it's one thing to pick it up and another to know it inside out :) I would say the first is good for regular agency work and the latter for serious application development
@jamespaxi Yes, but it is not far to go from "just picking it up" to being able to contribute effectively to a team
@jamepaxi is totally right -- I know the ins and outs of Python but I'm still harassing anyone and everyone all day long :)
@jamespaxi for sure! That is what I love about twitter and convore. They give unprecedented access to industry "luminaries" that you can't get anywhere else!
Doing fulltime since this year, I was part time to be able to go to my university. Want to hire a 3 years exp django dev? ping me ;-)
I do freelancing and consulting in the UK. Often got more work than I can handle, so thinking about taking on freelancers myself.

I'm currently fulltime and this is my first major django gig coming from PHP/Zend-Framework.  Prior to learning Django I had used python before as part of an enterprise geo-locational product/service that only had .NET and Python client libraries.  There are tons of django/python jobs in the NYC area.  And the NYC-Django meetup group usually opens with job announcements and there are always people looking for django devs for pretty much full-time or contract is needed.  People just want talented developers.
@danfairs what's the average daily rate for a django developer in UK?

@meitham Difficult to give a meaningful answer, it depends so much on your experience and the client's requirements and background. Ranges from £200 - £500/day, maybe. Like I said - such a wide range as to be almost worthless :)
